items.title: ‘People in L.A. are so gullible’: A $19 strawberry has sparked internet debate over luxury foods
items.summary:
- A $19 strawberry from Erewhon grocery in L.A. has gone viral, claimed to be the best-tasting strawberry worldwide.
- Influencer Alyssa Antoci, who is linked to Erewhon, reviews the strawberry, which has gained over 15 million views on TikTok.
- The strawberries are sold by Japanese fruit vendor Elly Amai, known for high-quality produce, and are individually packaged in a protective mini cloche.
- Public opinion is divided, with some calling L.A. customers gullible for paying such a price; others question the value compared to taste.
- This incidence follows previous high-priced items at Erewhon, including a $32 bag of ice, reflecting ongoing debates on luxury foods amid economic struggles.

items.title: ‘Battle-hardened’ Intuitive Machines takes its next steps toward a lunar economy
items.summary:
- Intuitive Machines (IM) made history with the first private soft landing on the moon a year ago.
- Their next mission, IM-2, is set to launch on February 26, 2025, from Kennedy Space Center.
- The lunar lander Athena will deliver NASA and commercial payloads, test exploration vehicles, and analyze lunar soil.
- The mission costs roughly $100 million and has secured profits through NASA’s Commercial Lunar Payload Services program.
- Water on the moon is essential for fuel and energy, which is vital for future lunar infrastructure projects.

items.title: Consumers are connected more than ever before
items.author: Sowmyanarayan Sampath
items.summary: - Technology is rapidly integrating into society, impacting consumer relationships. - Verizon’s annual Consumer Connections Report explores digital and physical shopping experiences and home connectivity trends. - Parents are using technology to monitor children's usage, focusing on apps like Tumblr and Snapchat. - Monthly data usage per Verizon Home Internet household increased to 656 GB. - Brick-and-mortar retail is rebounding, with 62% of Verizon customers purchasing in-store. - Fans utilize 5G technology to enhance their NFL game experience, with data use rising by 37% this season. - Holiday season data use at airports peaked at 17.7 million GB, with significant video usage.

items.title: Nvidia stock struggles before its first post-DeepSeek earnings: 5 things to watch
items.summary:
- Nvidia's fourth-quarter earnings report is highly anticipated following recent growth slowdowns and competition from AI advancements in China.
- Analysts predict revenue of $38.1 million and net income of $19.6 billion, with earnings of $0.85 per share for the quarter ending in January.
- Currently, Nvidia's shares are trading around the same price as last October, with a 61% increase over the past year but a 6% decrease in 2025, indicating potential demand issues for its chips.
- The earnings report is seen as a crucial moment for Nvidia's future growth and overall market impact, especially concerning the new Blackwell chip line and previous manufacturing challenges.

items.title: 21 federal workers resign from DOGE, refusing to ‘dismantle critical public services’
items.summary:
- 21 civil service employees resigned from Elon Musk’s Department of Government Efficiency, citing ethical concerns about dismantling public services.
- In a joint resignation letter, they stressed their commitment to serving the American people and upholding their constitutional oath.
- The resignation is part of broader challenges against Musk's efforts to reduce the federal workforce, drawing attention to political ideologues lacking the necessary skills for such a task.
- White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt dismissed the resignations, emphasizing President Trump's commitment to a more efficient government.
- The resigning staffers previously worked for the United States Digital Service, created during the Obama administration to improve government digital services.

items.title: Elon Musk’s DOGE is draining the life from the once-vaunted U.S. Digital Service
items.summary:
- The U.S. Digital Service (USDS) faces drastic changes after the establishment of Elon Musk’s Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE).
- Resignations began after the prior administration change; key figures like deputy administrator Ted Carstensen have left.
- Around 50 out of 150 USDS employees were laid off in DOGE’s initial layoffs, with personnel operating separately.
- The USDS has been renamed to the “U.S. DOGE Service,” giving it enhanced access to sensitive data and limited accountability.
- Many product managers and designers were laid off while engineers remained; former leaders expressed concerns over political interference.

items.title: Chengdu’s Snow Village faces backlash for creating a fake winter wonder
items.summary:
- Chengdu Snow Village opened with promised snowy attractions for Lunar New Year but faced warm weather.
- Organizers faked snow using white sheets, sand, and cotton wool, leading to disappointed visitors.
- The village received backlash, prompting an investigation by the Chengdu Culture and Tourism Bureau, and they later apologized and offered refunds.

items.title: Why Donald Trump and Elon Musk probably aren’t breaking up any time soon
items.summary:
- Anonymous hackers played an AI-generated video at HUD HQ depicting Trump kissing Musk’s feet, captioned "Long live the real king."
- Despite media efforts to portray a rift, Trump and Musk's alliance remains strong, contrary to predictions of a fallout.
- Trump acknowledged awareness of efforts to drive them apart during a recent appearance on Fox News alongside Musk.

items.title: How Factory is turning AI into ‘a junior developer in a box’
items.author: Matan Grinberg, Eno Reyes
items.summary:
- 25% of Google's code is now generated by AI.
- By 2028, 75% of enterprise developers expected to use AI tools.
- Factory, a startup, launched a platform that automates tasks in the software development lifecycle.
- Factory's CEO Matan Grinberg aims to bring autonomy to software engineering with 'Droids' to automate unwanted tasks.
- Grinberg and CTO Eno Reyes founded Factory in 2023 after discovering their passion for AI and software development.

items.title: Kate Bush, Annie Lennox, and a slew of other stars are on this silent album. Here’s why
items.summary:
- A new album titled "Is This What We Want?" features contributions from over 1,000 musicians, including Kate Bush and Annie Lennox, and includes the sound of silence.
- The album was released to protest British proposals regarding artificial intelligence laws that artists fear will compromise their creative control.
- The U.K. government is considering allowing tech firms to use copyrighted materials for AI training without explicit opt-out from creators.
- The album features recordings of empty studios to illustrate potential impacts on creative venues, with titles spelling out a message against music theft for AI benefit.
- Profits from the album will go to the charity Help Musicians.
- Ed Newton-Rex, composer and organizer of the album, highlighted concerns that the government’s proposal would be detrimental to musicians and unnecessary.

items.title: How LinkedIn became luxury fashion’s newest runway
items.summary:
- Fashion Week events are increasingly showcased on LinkedIn, marking a shift in how designers present collections.
- There has been a fivefold increase in live fashion show broadcasts on LinkedIn over the last three years, with 85% of luxury brands utilizing the platform.
- Brands like LVMH and Louis Vuitton adopted live shows on LinkedIn in 2019, successfully attracting nearly a million potential buyers shortly after events.
- LinkedIn's user demographics show over 30% are interested in fashion, making it a prime marketing tool for luxury brands.
- Stephanie Barret from LinkedIn highlights the platform's unique opportunity for luxury brands to engage with professionals in a focused environment.
- LinkedIn’s features, such as Live Event Ads, enhance audience engagement for fashion events, and luxury content sees high engagement rates compared to other platforms.

items.title: Inside Trello’s reinvention as a personal tasks app
items.summary:
- Trello has traditionally been viewed as a project management tool but will now pivot to a personal tasks app.
- Atlassian is announcing this significant change, shifting focus to individual users rather than teams.
- The updated Trello will maintain its versatile interface, allowing users to shape it for various personal uses.
- Most users will experience the new features in April 2023, marking a new era for Trello.

items.title: The iPhone 16e’s doesn’t have MagSafe—and that’s a problem
items.summary:
- The new iPhone 16e omits MagSafe, a significant feature introduced in 2020.
- The device has a single rear camera and two color options, aimed at a $600 price point.
- MagSafe is important for accessories like power banks and dashboard mounts, which enhance usability.
- Users can still utilize MagSafe accessories with a compatible case or sticker, but at reduced charging speeds.
- The lack of built-in MagSafe is a drawback for users who prefer a caseless phone or use thin cases.
- Competing devices may not have established similar magnetic attachment capabilities despite the Qi2 standard.

items.title: This music publisher wants to help ‘middle-class’ songwriters get the money they’re owed
items.summary:
- Kobalt music publisher launches Kosign to help emerging songwriters collect royalties.
- The music royalty system is complex, resulting in an estimated $1 billion in unclaimed royalties annually.
- Kosign targets independent artists who may not fit traditional publishing contracts, charges a $100 signup fee.
- Users can register globally and watch royalties hit their accounts in real-time with detailed metrics.
- Kobalt aims to be selective in membership to maintain service quality and effectiveness in royalty collection.

items.title: 5 Time-Saving Alexa Commands You’re Probably Not Using Yet
items.summary:
- Many Alexa users may only be using it for basic tasks like setting timers and playing music.
- Alexa can perform more advanced tasks, including checking traffic conditions.
- Users can gain information about commute times by simply asking Alexa after linking home and work addresses.
- Commands can also be used for managing shopping lists by adding items verbally.

items.title: Why today’s youth need more math, logic, and grammar skills
items.author: Rodrigo Magnago
items.summary:
- Emphasizes the importance of math, logic, and grammar skills for utilizing artificial intelligence.
- Discusses the foundational role of set theory in mathematics and its connection to logical reasoning.
- Stresses the relationship between grammatical syntax and mathematics, particularly in the context of programming languages and AI algorithms.
- Highlights the necessity for youth to develop natural algorithms through structured logical thinking and creativity.
- Points out the need for adjustments in educational curricula to prioritize foundational skills to keep pace with technological advancements.

items.title: Here are crypto’s biggest heists after Bybit’s $1.5 billion hack
items.summary:
- Bybit reported a hack resulting in the theft of $1.5 billion, the largest in crypto history.
- The stolen crypto was taken from a cold wallet primarily containing ether tokens.
- The heist amounts to more than double the previous largest theft and raised security concerns as hacking total exceeded $2 billion in 2024, continuing a trend of high-profile thefts since 2008.

items.title: What to know about Apple’s biggest-ever U.S. investment
items.summary:
- Apple announced a $500 billion investment in American manufacturing, engineering, and AI over the next four years.
- The announcement follows a meeting between Apple CEO Tim Cook and President Donald Trump regarding manufacturing practices and tariffs.
- The investment will include a 250,000-square-foot manufacturing facility in Houston, Texas, set to open in 2026, and the establishment of the Apple Manufacturing Academy in Detroit.

items.title: Anthropic’s new Claude AI model can decide between speed and deep thinking
items.summary:
- Anthropic released the Claude 3.7 Sonnet model, focusing on speed and 'chain of thought' reasoning.
- The model features an 'extended thinking' mode for detailed responses and a faster mode for simpler questions.
- It outperforms competitors like OpenAI's o1 and DeepSeek-R1 in benchmark tests but lags in specific areas like math and visual reasoning.
- Claude Code, a tool for coding tasks, can autonomously handle development tasks, claimed to save significant time.
- The model is available across all Claude subscription plans, with some features restricted to paid tiers.

items.title: Hunter Schafer Calls Out Trump's Passport Policy on TikTok
items.summary:
- Hunter Schafer shared her experience regarding passport gender markers in a TikTok video.
- Her passport reflects changes made under Trump’s January 20 executive order, which mandates recognition of only two genders.
- The State Department now issues passports only with male or female markers, disallowing the previously used X marker for non-binary individuals.
- Schafer's gender was incorrectly listed as male on her new passport after a replacement request following a theft.

items.title: How agentic AI will shape the future of business
items.summary: - Amazon introduced an AI-powered HR assistant in 2024 for performance reviews and workforce planning. - Tesla deployed AI personas for production monitoring and supply chain optimization. - AI personas are defined by their function, epistemic perspective, and relationship type, enabling organizations to streamline processes. - Agentic AI systems can autonomously make decisions and take actions based on real-time data. - Examples of agentic AI include Tesla's inventory management, JPMorgan’s adaptive trading algorithms, and Darktrace’s cyber defense. - Challenges include maintaining authenticity and trust, managing emotional engagement with AI, and setting boundaries for AI autonomy. - Effective AI integration requires purposeful design aligned with goals, a human-centered approach, ethical frameworks, and continuous monitoring. - The OPEN framework assists organizations in unlocking AI potential through systematic planning and experimentation, while the CARE framework helps manage AI-related risks. - The future of AI personas and agentic AI is promising, emphasizing the need for balancing technology with ethical considerations and human values.

items.title: Ai2’s Ali Farhadi advocates for open-source AI models. Here’s why
items.author: Ali Farhadi
items.summary:
- Ai2, led by CEO Ali Farhadi, aims to advance AI for humanity's benefit, emphasizing openness.
- The latest model, Tulu 3 405B, competes with OpenAI and DeepSeek, focusing on truly open AI systems.
- Farhadi believes closed practices hinder innovation and advocates for open-source principles in AI development.

items.title: How ‘lore’ became the internet’s favorite way to overshare
items.summary:
- The term 'lore' has evolved from its original meaning related to knowledge-sharing to a slang term reflecting personal identity online.
- It was a contender for Oxford University Press’s 2024 Word of the Year but lost to 'brain rot'.
- In modern usage, 'lore' includes sharing dramatic life stories, often seen on platforms like TikTok, with categories such as having lore, dropping lore, and dad lore.

items.title: These LinkedIn comedians are leaning into the cringe for clout
items.summary:
- Ben Sweeny, also known as Corporate Sween, uses satire to critique boring workplace practices on LinkedIn.
- His video, suggesting humorous ways to engage employees, has garnered over 5,000 views.
- Comedians are increasingly using LinkedIn as a platform to reach new audiences.
- LinkedIn has reported a 36% increase in video creation, outpacing other post formats.
- Humor is considered important for workplace connections according to LinkedIn's editor-in-chief Dan Roth.

items.title: The best apps to find new books
items.summary:
- **Libby**: Free e-books and audiobooks through libraries in 78 countries, supports multiple library cards, digital only.
- **Kanopy**: Offers free access to films and documentaries via library login, video limits may apply.
- **Hoopla**: Works with 3,900 library systems, offers audiobooks, e-books, comics, movies, and more.
- **World Cat**: Locate books across 10,000 libraries globally.
- **Most Recommended Books**: Lists recommended books from experts and celebrities.
- **Whichbook’s World Map**: Find books set in specific countries.
- **Project Gutenberg**: Over 75,000 free e-books available without registration.
- **Bookbub**: Shows discounted and free e-books.
- **Alibris**: Online marketplace for 200 million titles from independent booksellers.
- **Sora**: E-library for kids offered through schools with access to various formats.

items.title: 5 tips for mastering virtual communication
items.author: Andrew Brodsky
items.summary:
- Instant messaging, email, video calls have replaced in-person communication in workplaces.
- The PING framework provides best practices for effective virtual communication.
- Importance of perspective taking in avoiding misinterpretations during virtual interactions.
- Miscommunication can arise from being self-focused rather than considering the recipient's context.
- Even seemingly clear communication can be perceived differently without shared context.

items.title: This slick new service puts ChatGPT, Perplexity, and Wikipedia on the map
items.summary:
- A new app has been launched that combines Google Maps with ChatGPT, Perplexity, and Wikipedia.
- The app aims to blend classic and AI technology to create a unique user experience.
- Released recently, it promises to offer exciting functionalities and uncover little-known tech treasures.

items.title: The next wave of AI is here: Autonomous AI agents are amazing—and scary
items.summary:
- The surge in interest around AI makes it hard to distinguish hype from reality.
- Autonomous AI agents can interact with the environment, make decisions, and learn, marking a significant shift in AI usage.
- Generative AI tools have been largely human-supervised, but advancements are allowing AI to act more independently.
- Bill Gates suggests these AI agents could revolutionize the software industry, similar to the shift from text commands to graphical interfaces.

items.title: Apple’s hidden white noise feature may be just the productivity boost you need
items.summary:
- The Mac's "Background Sounds" feature generates sounds like gentle waves to aid focus.
- The pandemic highlighted the author's reliance on background noise for productivity.
- Traditional music can be distracting, while ambient sounds from videos proved beneficial for concentration.
- The author advocates for using ambient sounds to enhance focus and creativity while working.

items.title: The government or 4chan? The White House’s social media account is sparking outreach
items.summary:
- The White House's social media account received backlash for posts resembling 4chan content.
- A Valentine’s card post on February 14 led to 36.6 million views, sparking divided reactions.
- Another post on February 18 featured an ASMR video about deportation, eliciting criticism for trivializing serious issues.
- White House spokesman Harrison Fields defended the approach, emphasizing direct communication with the public.

items.title: How Wikipedia became a political lightening rod
items.summary:
- Wikipedia faces unprecedented political threats, potentially reaching a breaking point.
- Republican attacks label Wikipedia as a ‘woke’ institution, escalating scrutiny from figures like Elon Musk.
- Leaked documents reveal plans by The Heritage Foundation to expose Wikipedia editors and undermine the platform.
- Critics allege Wikipedia has a liberal bias, leading to initiatives like Conservapedia.
- Musk's recent comments sparked calls to defund Wikipedia, prompting backlash from cofounder Jimmy Wales.
- Internal discussions at Wikimedia express concern over rising threats against Wikipedia and its editors.

items.title: Why a proposed ban on lab-grown meat is getting pushback from Nebraska ranchers
items.author: Maregery A. Beck
items.summary:
- Nebraska proposes a ban on lab-grown meat amid pushback from ranchers who argue they can compete in a free market.
- Governor Jim Pillen supports the ban, aiming to protect traditional meat producers, with an executive order previously signed to restrict procurement of lab-grown meat.
- Ranchers like Dan Morgan advocate for competition, stating regulation should focus on safety and labeling, leaving consumer choice intact.
- Approximately a dozen states have proposed similar bans; Florida and Alabama have already enacted them.
- Opposition highlights concerns regarding safety, yet many believe the ban serves to protect existing agricultural interests rather than public health.
- The cultivation process of lab-grown meat involves using animal cells in bioreactors to grow muscle and fat tissue, although it is still in development stages.

items.title: Trump’s China tariffs will hit small device makers hardest
items.summary:
- ZapperBox raised the price of its over-the-air DVR on Amazon to $300 due to a 10% tariff on goods from China.
- Founder Gopal Miglani states that manufacturing relocation to Taiwan has increased costs, and reversing the changes would be expensive.
- Smaller companies are more affected by tariffs compared to larger tech firms like Apple and Amazon, which can absorb costs more easily.
- AstroPad is considering price increases and is exploring manufacturing in Vietnam, but emphasizes the quality and pricing advantages of Chinese production.

items.title: This new AI tool helps Walmart’s merchandising team plan what’s in stores
items.summary:
• Walmart introduced Wally, an internal generative AI tool for its merchandising team to quickly analyze data and create reports.
• Wally can determine product details without the need for precise terminology, making data inquiries easier for merchants.
• The tool reportedly saves time for merchants and improves data accessibility, having been introduced to them about a month ago.

items.title: Substack Bets Big on Video as TikTok’s Future Remains Uncertain
items.summary:
- Substack now allows video posts to be published directly from the app, enabling mobile uploads and monetization.
- This update aims to help creators build engaged communities and bypass algorithms restricting reach.
- Substack offers tools for tracking post views, new subscribers, and revenue impact, with plans for more features like editing tools and customizable paywalls.
- The launch of the $20 million Creator Accelerator Fund incentivizes creators to join Substack without revenue loss.
- Expansion of Live Video has been made available to all publishers on the platform.

items.title: ‘It’s like their escape’: Retro gaming is back thanks to Gen Z
items.summary:
- Retro gaming is revived, particularly among Gen Z, with 24% owning retro consoles.
- A survey by Pringles shows 66% of Britons bought retro tech in the last two years.
- Popular retro consoles include Game Boy, Super Nintendo, and original Xbox, all discontinued years ago.
- 89% of gamers find retro games a break from the internet; 74% find them relaxing.
- A Retro Console Clinic by Pringles in London offered free repairs and encouraged retro gaming.
- 78% enjoy using retro gadgets to avoid smartphones; 21% of Gen Z wish smartphones never existed.
- The nostalgia trend continues to grow, with significant engagement on platforms like TikTok.

items.title: Netflix to invest $1 billion in Mexico production over next 4 years
items.author: Ted Sarandos
items.summary:
- Netflix announces a $1 billion investment in Mexico for film and TV production over the next four years.
- The investment aims to produce around 20 films and TV series annually.
- CEO Ted Sarandos expresses intentions to partner with more local producers.
- Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum highlights job creation and economic benefits from the investment.
- Previous Netflix investments in Mexican productions include award-winning projects like "Roma" and "Club de Cuervos."

items.title: Grok 3 model puts xAI at the top tier of frontier model developers
items.summary:
- Elon Musk’s xAI has launched the Grok 3 large language model, outperforming models like OpenAI’s GPT-4o in benchmarks.
- Grok 3 was trained using 100,000 Nvidia H100 GPUs, with early testers giving positive feedback.
- Despite impressive performance, it struggled with specific prompts, suggesting room for improvement.
- Future benchmarks are expected to clarify Grok 3's competitive standing as the field evolves rapidly.

items.title: TikTok Parents Claim Butter Helps Babies Sleep Better
items.summary:
- A TikTok trend suggests that giving babies a tablespoon or two of butter before bed improves their sleep.
- Users report significant sleep improvements for their toddlers after introducing butter, with claims of sleeping 8 hours straight.
- Pediatric experts warn there is no scientific evidence supporting the trend and advise against giving babies butter for sleep, highlighting potential digestive issues and choking hazards.
- Recommended alternatives for better sleep include kiwi, cherries, milk, fatty fish, nuts, and rice, but solid food is not advisable for babies under 6 months.

items.title: Google is looking at this location for its first retail stores outside the U.S.
items.summary:
- Google is planning to open its first physical retail stores outside the U.S. in India.
- The company is considering locations in New Delhi and Mumbai, with plans to open stores around 15,000 square feet.
- The timeline for opening these stores is at least six months, but this could change.
- Google aims to replicate Apple's successful retail strategy and has previously invested $10 billion in India as a key growth market.
- Currently, Google has only five retail stores, all located in the U.S.

items.title: Trump's Tariffs on China Could Risk Access to Rare Earth Elements Widely Used in Tech Sector
items.author: Damian J. Troise
items.summary:
- The U.S. relies on China for over 80% of its rare earth elements, crucial for defense and tech.  
- Trump imposed 10% tariffs on all Chinese imports, leading to Chinese retaliatory tariffs on U.S. goods.  
- The International Energy Agency predicts demand for rare earth elements will surge by 72% by 2030, while supply is expected to lag behind.  
- Geopolitical tensions are rising as nations seek alternative sources of rare earth metals outside of China.

items.title: Gen Z Learns the Hard Way: Be Cautious with Financial Advice from TikTok
items.summary:
- 77% of Gen Z and 61% of millennials seek financial advice from social media.
- TikTok has become a popular platform for financial advice among Gen Z, utilizing the hashtag FinTok.
- Despite some successes, 39% of Gen Z and 33% of millennials will never again trust financial advice from social media.
- 37% of Gen Z and 25% of millennials faced negative consequences like IRS audits from following such advice.
- Notably, 64% of Gen Z found positive impacts from the financial advice received from influencers, despite the risks.

items.title: Quantum computing breakthrough? Microsoft says its new Majorana 1 chip shows we’re closer than ever
items.summary:
- Microsoft unveiled a new chip, the Majorana 1, claiming quantum computing is closer than previously thought, potentially just years away.
- Quantum computing could revolutionize fields like medicine and chemistry, but poses risks to current cybersecurity systems.
- The Majorana 1 chip is reported to have fewer errors compared to competitors, with a scientific paper to be published in *Nature* providing evidence.
- Opinions vary in the tech industry regarding the timeline for practical quantum computing, with predictions ranging from 5 to 20 years.

items.title: Trump keeps cutting election security jobs. Here’s what’s at risk
items.summary:
- The Trump administration is dismantling federal agencies, affecting the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA).
- CISA, responsible for election security, has put multiple election security team members on administrative leave.
- Over 130 members of CISA were also fired as part of government cuts aimed at eliminating waste and incompetence.

items.title: AT&T debuts new plan, making it easier to split the bill on shared plans
items.author: Chris Morris
items.summary:
[AT&T introduces SplitPay](https://www.fastcompany.com/91108177/why-att-turned-its-new-ad-into-a-reunion-for-the-office), allowing individual billing on shared plans to ease payment sharing among users.
The service will be available immediately and was developed over the past year, with plans to patent the technology.
Primary account holders remain responsible for payments, but users will receive texts to prompt their payments with notifications for overdue payments.

items.title: Playing by the rules of AI
items.author: Juan Orlandini
items.summary:
- The future of AI is influenced by evolving regulations and practices in the business sector.
- California legislation is setting early standards for AI regulation in the U.S., inspired by the EU Artificial Intelligence Act.
- Organizations are encouraged to define best practices for AI implementation to ensure compliance and leverage growth opportunities.
- Three categories of AI governance: AI creators, AI adapters, and AI consumers, each facing unique regulatory challenges.
- Businesses must focus on practical AI applications, ensuring data integrity, compliance, and ethical practices.
- Six practical steps proposed for organizations to establish solid AI standards, including starting with internal applications and surrounding themselves with knowledgeable teams.

items.title: The iPhone 16E is here. Here are 5 ways it’s different from the iPhone SE
items.summary:
- Apple introduced the iPhone 16E as the replacement for the iPhone SE, marking its first new product of 2025.
- The iPhone 16E features a new design with a 6.1-inch display, resembling modern iPhones like the iPhone 15 and 16.
- The new model adopts Face ID for biometric authentication, replacing the former Touch ID system.

items.title: Malaysia is looking to data centers to boost its economy, but experts warn of risks
items.author: Anirruddha Ghoshal, Vincent Thian, Eileen Ng, Matt O’Brien
items.summary:
- Malaysia's Johor province is quickly becoming a leading market for data centers, expected to reach 1.6 gigawatts by 2023.
- Concerns arise over competition for energy as local businesses struggle with outages caused by storms, resulting in substantial losses.
- Experts warn that data centers consume extensive land, water, and energy, often delivering fewer jobs than anticipated, and are criticized for practices likened to 'digital colonialism'.
- The country is receiving over $31 billion in investments for data centers, increasing anxiety over sustainability and resource management.

items.title: Airbnb is suing New Orleans over regulatory ‘regime’
items.author: Jack Brook
items.summary:
- Airbnb is suing New Orleans for requiring compliance with city laws for short-term rentals.
- City Council President J.P. Morrell stated the lawsuit implies Airbnb does not want regulation.
- New Orleans has faced challenges managing illegal short-term rentals while addressing affordable housing needs.
- In 2023, new regulations were adopted but enforcement has been difficult, with many illegal listings persisting.
- The lawsuit claims the city’s regulations represent a punitive enforcement regime and burdensome requirements for Airbnb.
- There are about 1,350 legal short-term rental properties versus over 7,000 active Airbnb listings in the city.
- The city has a significant affordable housing crisis, with a deficit of 47,000 units for lower-income residents.

items.title: This AI trend lets TikTok users relive history’s best—and worst—moments
items.summary:
- A new TikTok trend allows users to experience historical events through AI-generated POV videos.
- Creator @timetravellerpov has gained over 329,000 followers since starting in early 2023, with videos depicting various eras and scenarios.
- Popular examples include experiencing life during the Black Plague in 1351 London and various significant historical events like 9/11 and JFK's assassination.
- The videos aim to evoke nostalgia and curiosity, providing immersive experiences that feel realistic despite their historical accuracy.
